column4: How do I reset or change the root password without screwing everything up?
ah, but I messed with permissions and cannot sudo properly
do you have a user that can sudo (the original user)?
root password from default is disabled.  sudo passwd" enables it
I changed permissions so that a seperate password would be used for my user account and the root, and now I cannot sudo and also cannot use the root password I set
you need to edit /etc/group and allow sudo access to create a root passwd
if you have already set a root password then kill it with "sudo passwd -l root"  then recreate it with "sudo passwd".  To access root use the command "su" *not* sudo
also, the root password I set does not seem to work.  Can I reset it without root permissions?
but I need a password to sudo
I think if you load up the livecd you could mount the partition then edit /etc/groups
that would let me use my user password to sudo things?
as opposed to the unknown root password
yes, need to make the user an 'admin' i believe
thank you.  I will try that.
that would give you sudo access back.  then with sudo access you can enable the root account.  Remember you can't (default) login as root over ssh
